note.div:
SOA supports two core business strategies
Growing top-line revenue (Enterprise reacts quickly to requirements from the market - Business processes can be reconfigured rather than reimplemented)
Improving bottom-line profit (Saving development costs by resuing existing services)

ul.li: Multiple protocols problem, multiple vendor problem

note.div:
ESB is a central intermediary in SOA
ESB serves as a message broker (can mix and match protocols)
ESB can hide changes in location of services without affecting clients
ESB can pool sessions, enrich messages, etc.

ul.li: synchronous = one socket, only the server defines endpoint, response time must be relatively small
asynchronous = request and response each have sockets, response time can be large (hours, even days)
Blocking I/O generally means when an I/O operation is being processed, the thread is being blocked
Blocking I/O is not good for network applications, because connections require their own threads and large number of threads means large overhead

Non-blocking (asynchronous) I/O usually uses some kind of worker threads, which process the requests asynchronously (I/O doesn't block the thread, the worker thread process other requests while I/O is processed)
